document.title: Pennsylvania Assessment Anchors and Eligible Content

8A484BDD11334256801EEAB66D9A37AE.description:
Describe the causes of seasonal change as they relate to the
revolution of Earth and the tilt of Earth’s axis.

3DF5CDDE374A4BF999C745DABC3BEFF4.description:
Explain how the motion of the Sun - Earth - Moon system relates to time
(e.g., days, months, years).

65E2B1B0DD1B41F59B8B0E6EC8D62324.description: Describe motions of the Sun - Earth - Moon system.

95FD645A2CA3491ABE5F774B6684F84C.description: Describe Earth’s relationship to the Sun and the Moon.

23D5C337F453491F83293DAB50178774.description: Composition and Structure of the Universe

AEE634582A6B49E88F56F462252C8109.description:
Identify appropriate instruments (i.e., thermometer, rain gauge, weather vane,
anemometer, and barometer) to study weather and what they measure.

81BEC3189458427CBC2255E1F9A0D519.description:
Identify weather patterns from data charts or graphs of the data (e.g., temperature, wind direction, wind speed, cloud types,
precipitation).

74960ACF47144E6E9156589B47025BC6.description:
Identify basic cloud types (i.e., cirrus, cumulus, stratus, and cumulonimbus) and
make connections to basic elements of weather (e.g., changes in temperature, precipitation).

757AAA5F6F2F4CAF9DBB0112AA43D096.description: Identify basic weather conditions and how they are measured.

8A2B41E18D5142A4903915588A577224.description:
Explain the role and relationship of a watershed or a wetland on water sources
(e.g., water storage, groundwater recharge, water filtration, water source, water cycle).

3045C35B34834FE7B596CE09C390AFFF.description:
Describe or compare lentic systems (i.e., ponds, lakes, and bays) and lotic systems
(i.e., streams, creeks, and rivers).

CFEACF37876447989287BE039621BD32.description:
Explain how water goes through phase changes (i.e., evaporation, condensation,
freezing, and melting).

4395883546F9406EA7BD7EE88E74125E.description:
Describe types of freshwater and saltwater bodies (e.g., lakes, rivers,
wetlands, oceans).

034D72D4A4654F19AAC15BF9112087B3.description:
Describe Earth’s different sources of water or describe changes in the form
of water.

50DB017410874E06AE289BF07BE1EF49.description:
Recognize ways that humans benefit from the use of water resources (e.g.,
agriculture, energy, recreation).

A638A1BD19274942B539663838D68C0A.description:
Identify the types and uses of Earth materials for renewable, nonrenewable,
and reusable products (e.g., human-made products: concrete, paper, plastics, fabrics).

0A542EDFC17D46BBA47193FBA31BE6A9.description:
Identify products and by-products of plants and animals for human use (e.g., food,
clothing, building materials, paper products).

05F68B9BC8884442B56912B32C7D343B.description: Identify the types and uses of Earth’s resources.

5B19B09E26C34E43821FA7FE1AAF4879.description:
Describe the composition of soil as weathered rock and decomposed organic
remains.

D8E9DC6EE3C64F43A512FC7AE0FB97F4.description:
Identify various Earth structures (e.g., mountains, watersheds, peninsulas,
lakes, rivers, valleys) through the use of models.

BD4966D4816140578508C4FB5853D647.description:
Describe how prominent Earth features in Pennsylvania (e.g., mountains, valleys,
caves, sinkholes, lakes, rivers) were formed.

229C0C8B765B405CB41A9C4B44A14CCD.description: Earth Features and Processes that Change Earth and Its Resources

A425818827384C099059F2DD5BAD817D.description:
Describe the position of an object by locating it relative to another object or
a stationary background (e.g., geographic direction, left, up).

63289D686BE7460295E425E0405B4264.description:
Compare the relative movement of objects or describe types of motion
that are evident (e.g., bouncing ball, moving in a straight line, back and forth, merry-go-round).

906FDCBD525A4436B41998E03312AD97.description:
Describe changes in motion caused by forces (e.g., magnetic, pushes or
pulls, gravity, friction).

805B04F9244D4225802F12994C2DFD13.description:
Identify and describe different types of force and motion resulting from these
forces, or the effect of the interaction between force and motion.

9C6357CD42BA408B81EBE982C70009E9.description: Identify characteristics of sound (e.g., pitch, loudness, reflection).

ADE6192ADE844309A39435DE2E65E472.description:
Recognize or illustrate simple direct current series and parallel circuits
composed of batteries, light bulbs (or other common loads), wire, and on/off switches.

1F95736A44B54E49B4E8B7397669CB62.description:
Describe the flow of energy through an object or system (e.g., feeling
radiant heat from a light bulb, eating food to get energy, using a battery to light a bulb or run a fan).

6596D42FAF934ED9808CBDA7D0D8DB01.description:
Identify energy forms, energy transfer, and energy examples (e.g., light,
heat, electrical).

BE538DD3DED94DB2964C6CD117E37B38.description:
Recognize basic energy types and sources, or describe how energy can be
changed from one form to another.

02D32532F8784E2CB98BF4C57B9C4BDD.description: Forms, Sources, Conversion, and Transfer of Energy

43CB898A9FD64ACF9DF8856EC09F36AF.description:
Use physical properties [e.g., mass, shape, size, volume, color, texture, magnetism, state (i.e., solid, liquid,
and gas), conductivity (i.e., electrical and heat)] to describe matter.

1CB2EE63EC6A478BAD8506C4C2BC8C32.description: Describe observable physical properties of matter.

D7B8F3F908A64CFC833BB8766DD3CB98.description: Structure, Properties, and Interaction of Matter and Energy

4BE966D9C8F944DDAB9859F5095CA673.description: Describe the effects of pollution (e.g., litter) in the community.

A4EE9C93E49D4227BC4C574712FD0DC8.description:
Identify major land uses in the urban, suburban and rural communities (e.g.,
housing, commercial, recreation).

9EE8CA9915514412BCEF12624021A093.description:
Identify biological pests (e.g., fungi – molds, plants – foxtail, purple
loosestrife, Eurasian water milfoil; animals – aphides, ticks, zebra mussels, starlings, mice) that compete with humans for resources.

312BA5511AA948F4A0C2E05DDEB2CC42.description:
Describe the human dependence on the food and fiber systems from production
to consumption (e.g., food, clothing, shelter, products).

0B121D3E0CB947BEB754311A622BA697.description:
Identify everyday human activities (e.g., driving, washing, eating, manufacturing,
farming) within a community that depend on the natural environment.

CA855A8B9DEA4ADE8BCE67E6C2C062C4.description:
Identify and describe human reliance on the environment at the individual or the
community level.

67F4E88A0B254EDE996BD6FFB8B70FC1.description:
Explain and predict how changes in seasons affect plants, animals, or daily
human life (e.g., food availability, shelter, mobility).

604103E4A2BD409582A7DBF516702F70.description:
Describe and predict how changes in the environment (e.g., fire, pollution, flood,
building dams) can affect systems.

087E2268EC7A4A79855EB38B27A711A9.description: Describe what happens to a living thing when its habitat is changed.

EE4B96BF09E3494CBFBF46BD7C9C739A.description: Describe, explain, and predict change in natural or human-made systems and the possible effects of those changes on the environment.

6FE31083F599471F85745C9FB4AB1CFF.description:
Describe interactions between living and nonliving components (e.g. plants – water, soil, sunlight, carbon dioxide, temperature; animals – food, water,
shelter, oxygen, temperature) of a local ecosystem.

2F8576C7A90F4DB681B3C3B8FB11D831.description:
Describe the living and nonliving components of a local ecosystem (e.g.,
lentic and lotic systems, forest, cornfield, grasslands, city park, playground).

486B9C5F6EF94CA0AD4F28BA4220A50C.description:
Identify and describe living and nonliving things in the environment and
their interaction.

C56C710478274098AF8CB3DF0B9E02F1.description:
Identify physical characteristics (e.g., height, hair color, eye color, attached
earlobes, ability to roll tongue) that appear in both parents and could be passed on to offspring.

6F85D7A317E645D4AA7B6735194CF7F7.description:
Identify that characteristics are inherited and, thus, offspring closely resemble
their parents.

5550ABC2A462462293922CCA83FA46ED.description:
Explain how specific adaptations can help a living organism survive (e.g.,
protective coloration, mimicry, leaf sizes and shapes, ability to catch or retain water).

7FC70206C22C40708869BF75B4B790A5.description:
Identify characteristics for plant and animal survival in different
environments (e.g., wetland, tundra, desert, prairie, deep ocean, forest).

3BF81D716DED4D0C85A75CABC2932ADB.description: Identify and explain how adaptations help organisms to survive.

706D524348D644BDAF41B9F7EA255FE0.description:
Describe the life cycles of different organisms (e.g., moth, grasshopper,
frog, seed-producing plant).

8E7C847887354F7C86FDC69D95CD0EE6.description:
Describe how different parts of a living thing work together to provide what
the organism needs (e.g., parts of plants: roots, stems, leaves).

1D27EFC06BC44AB78AD33F71213C5773.description: Describe basic needs of plants and animals (e.g., air, water, food).

F2B4FD2F2B124CF59330636761F88A9A.description:
Compare similar functions of external characteristics of organisms (e.g.,
anatomical characteristics: appendages, type of covering, body segments).

D2F321B364C7464794CD8CBF9D956900.description: Identify life processes of living things (e.g., growth, digestion, respiration).

E14D8E06788444F091CECEFC956D4EED.description:
Identify and describe similarities and differences between living things and
their life processes.

8DDAC795D7174B2E91E0AF8AECD5F0AF.description:
Predict future conditions/events based on observable patterns (e.g.,
day/night, seasons, sunrise/sunset, lunar phases).

6B1A7D909F8D49708ACCBEF3C1C85A48.description:
Identify and describe observable patterns (e.g., growth patterns in
plants, weather, water cycle).

57F2FB16207345C289BB6FF07A8CAF42.description:
Identify and make observations about patterns that regularly occur and
reoccur in nature.

793CB56A292F462CBCF89A53533D45DF.description:
Use appropriate, simple modeling tools and techniques to describe or
illustrate a system (e.g., two cans and string to model a communications system, terrarium to model an ecosystem).

1EA109D34C844A92BB54CCDB834530C7.description:
Use models to make observations to explain how systems work (e.g., water
cycle, Sun-Earth-Moon system).

CB9942FDA1E0463D8995ACC88D3B32A0.description:
Identify what different models represent (e.g., maps show physical
features, directions, distances; globes represent Earth; drawings of watersheds depict terrain; dioramas show ecosystems; concept maps show relationships of ideas).

CE41EDA408884E74816016C31FF862FF.description:
Use models to illustrate simple concepts and compare the models to what they
represent.

D88DBC725FEF44CD8D73ECAD05BB9F1E.description:
Identify the parts of the food and fiber systems as they relate to agricultural
products from the source to the consumer.

BEFEC2D188D743308F3A9E1F5DACA7E3.description:
Categorize the parts of an ecosystem as either living or nonliving and
describe their roles in the system.

945887E167D4497A9BF540CA2CDE4F04.description:
Explain a relationship between the living and nonliving components in a
system (e.g., food web, terrarium).

9FD2BF9C200B40CEB0074974C92DAE65.description:
Categorize systems as either natural or human-made (e.g., ballpoint pens,
simple electrical circuits, plant anatomy, water cycle).

F2C6A56889B64ABE982BE2CAD1C44C12.description:
Identify systems and describe relationships among parts of a familiar system (e.g., digestive system, simple
machines, water cycle).

6202F4C7E426497081C33EA11C40D619.description:
Identify appropriate tools or instruments for specific tasks and describe the information they can
provide (e.g., measuring: length - ruler, mass - balance scale, volume - beaker, temperature - thermometer; making observations: hand lens, binoculars, telescope).

404237141EEA427B81451CBEE1683095.description:
Identify appropriate instruments for a specific task and describe the
information the instrument can provide.

98574180FDAE48F0A9E035E807F957AC.description: State a conclusion that is consistent with the information/data.

18253FFB1BEE4751AF60551EC3D643B4.description:
Observe a natural phenomenon (e.g., weather changes, length of
daylight/night, movement of shadows, animal migrations, growth of plants), record observations, and then make a prediction based on those observations.

941E7F2FA14440B795E2202C05B1531F.description: Design and describe an investigation (a fair test) to test one variable.

6B9C6E7FBBD94479B5E237FF3161FCE5.description:
Generate questions about objects, organisms, or events that can be
answered through scientific investigations.

0A339AABF24F4161B16A43E541E0255F.description:
Apply skills necessary to conduct an experiment or design a solution to solve
a problem.

45299D4A4DF34ACD9C9C62145E140FEA.description: Processes, Procedures, and Tools of Scientific Investigations

B17D46D2BFEB4475B6DD223A571D81B3.description:
Provide examples, predict, or describe how everyday human activities (e.g.,
solid waste production, food production and consumption, transportation, water consumption, energy production and use) may change the environment.

99F0E5A171C64A1D8476EBC40AEF2AA7.description:
Explain what happens to a living organism when its food supply, access
to water, shelter, or space is changed (e.g., it might die, migrate, change behavior, eat something else).

0EB7C6AA356F4CA88CE970767C839F25.description:
Observe and describe the change to objects caused by temperature change
or light.

6E384D025ED74FB7809E99F6D0600449.description: Describe relative size, distance, or motion.

6F7E88043AE14797BDE56EE650AA7396.description: Observe and record change by using time and measurement.

F07BC3CA54844BBC9D94F59FA29F14CA.description:
Recognize and describe change in natural or human-made systems and
the possible effects of those changes.

01208E8F916F4FBFB7745356BC6CFE2A.description:
Identify and describe examples of common technological changes past to
present in the community (e.g., energy production, transportation, communications, agriculture, packaging materials) that have either positive or negative impacts on society or the environment.

6992A34DD4F24EB69247AE3EE1784DBC.description:
Distinguish between a scientific fact and an opinion, providing clear explanations
that connect observations and results (e.g., a scientific fact can be supported by making observations).

58A37ADDAEC4421AA109C89E78A3DFC2.description:
Identify and explain the application of scientific, environmental, or
technological knowledge to possible solutions to problems.
